XRobbins, Rossell Hope. “Signs of Death in Middle English.” Mediaeval Studies 32 (1970): 282-98.
_description: Signs of death — fourteen to twenty-two lines in couplets.

BLHar7322.First Lines:
Whanne þe ffet coldetȝand þe tunge
                    ffoldetȝ…
BLHar7322.Last Lines: …And of þat erer was hisNou shal he hauen mys
BLHar7322.Editions:
Furnivall,  Frederick James,
                        ed.  
             Political, Religious and Love Poems, from Lambeth MS. 306 and other
                sources.
EETS
         o.s. 15 (1866); repr. 1962; rev. ed. 1903: 220-1; rev. ed. 249-50.

BLRoy7Eiv.First Lines: Wan his fet coldetand the tonge foldet…
BLRoy7Eiv.Last Lines:
…Quia sic hoc cognitarent for al þe worl hus wynea nolden
                    don a dedlische sene

OxfOriel10.First Lines: Whanne his fete coldelthAnd pe tonge foldeth…
OxfOriel10.Last Lines:
…In þy myrpe þenke in þisAnd þou shalt
                    neuer do amys
OxfOriel10.Editions:
Fletcher,  Alan J. 
             “A Death Lyric from the Summa predicantium, MS Oriel College 10.” 
             Notes and Queries
         n.s. 24 [222] (1977): 11-12: 11.
